comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content:
This is the full entry for the relevant works on the DIA:
Name:KAYE-PARRY & ROSS Building:CO. DUBLIN, DUBLIN, ST STEPHEN'S GREEN, NO. 027-31 (SHELBOURNE HOTEL) Date:1900-1903;1906 Nature:New kitchens, 1900 (£4,000); 2 additional storeys, 1901-2 (Contractor: W. & A. Roberts. £3,000;£1,921); additional storey to Kildare St wing; new electric lift at main staircase, 1906 (£2,454).
I read this as two additional storeys in 1901-02 and a later additional storey to the Kildare St wing in 1906. I'm thinking that the 1901-02 works refers to the Georgian building immediately to the right of the main hotel building and that the 1906 works refers to the Kildare Street mansard roof - as there was already a mansard roof here as seen in [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/]'s photo above it really is an addition of only one storey.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: James Adam and Sons, across Kildare Street from the Shelbourne, use this very image, bicycle and all, on their Company page.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is a shot from 1951, and the building to the right is at today's height:

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's another NLI photo with the building to the right raised This is from the Robert French collection so latest date 1914. Hard to tell but I don't think the Kildare Street addition is here which would put this photo at 1902-1906 and would back up the theory that the two storey extension in 1901-02 refers to the Georgian house.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content:
My reading of the timescale of roof additions is as follows:

1901-1902: additional two storeys to Georgian building on St Stephen's Green (to right of main hotel)
1906: additional storey to Kildare Street wing (incl. mansard roof)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: So, which horse tram route is running along Stephens Green (East) and turning down Merrion Row? The Donnybrook and Phoenix Park via Stephen's Green route opened in 1906 as an electric line. I think the one we see is the Kingsbridge railway station and Harcourt St. railway station (corner of Hatch Street) via southern quays and Westland Row railway station route, which was electrified in January 1900. Yes, see www.dublinbusstuff.com/Routes90.html: The line would open on the 3rd June 1872, with horse trams operating on the following route: King’s Bridge, Victoria Quay, Usher’s Island, Usher’s Quay, Merchant’s Quay, Wood Quay, Essex Quay, Wellington Quay, Aston Quay, D’olier Street, Pearse Street (then Great Brunswick Street), Westland Row, Merrion Street Lower, Merrion Square West, Merrion Street Upper, (Ely Place, Hume Street returning Merrion Row), St. Stephen’s Green East, Earlsfort Terrace (terminating at the Exhibition Palace now the National Concert Hall).

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Daring Robbery In The Shelbourne Hotel (1880)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In 1881 the proprietor of the Shelbourne Hotel were the Jury family ( I wonder if they are connected to the Jury who founded Jury's Inn?).. A dispute over a will led to a case heard  in the Chancery Division (December 1881). The case was Jury v Jury, probably one of the few court cases ever where a Jury lost the case.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Freeman's carried a lengthy description of the "new" Shelbourne Hotel the day after its official opening on Feb 21st 1867 . The novel concept of a movable boudoir "lift" had to be explained to the Freeman's readership
The great height of the building might suggest a difficulty as to the mode of getting comfortably to the top. This is obviated by the fact that one of the appurtenances is a "lift". Leaving technicalities aside this is nothing more or less that a movable room. Those who wish to go to the upper floors have only to walk into this room, in which six persons can comfortably sit, and they will, with the aid of steam machinery and a waiter, ascend to the landing, in which they are billeted without being much more than aware that they are moving. The probability of the rope breaking was suggested by some of the visitors yesterday, but Mr Cotton, who kindly showed them over the building and explained everything, dispelled any fears by stating that the rope had been three times cut the previous day, and that, owing to mechanical arrangements the "lift" rested on supports "in that case made and provided." The machine ascends to the top of the house in one minute.
 However ... (Freeman's Dec 14th 1882)
ACCIDENT TO A LADY Yesterday, In the Shelbourne Hotel, while Mrs Hughes, widow of Baron Hughes, was ascending in one of the "lifts", the lift, from some unaccountable reason, gave way and was precipitated down about two flights of stairs. The lady received a severe shock. Reports of an exaggerated character were spread throughout the city about the accident, but we believe no serious injury was sustained.
 No doubt Mr Cotton was unavailable for comment.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Nubian statues: The 1867 description of the hotel also includes
The front presents a beautiful effect. Two fine bays rising to the height of the third storey and surrounded by stone battlements, flank the portico leading to the grand central entrance. The upper windows are louvred, and all are furnished with plate glass. The portico, or rather porch, is sustained by Corinthian pillars. On the four pedestals which sustain an elegantly wrought iron paling stand finely cast bronze figures of Assyrian mutes, holding sockets for globes and gasburners

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: The comments on your wonderful pictures are sometimes hilarious ( and informative of course).....but where did "Nubian Mute" come from?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] Wikipedia calls them "Nubian princesses and their shackled slave girls". Freeman's journal called them "Assyran mutes". I confused the two appellations and came up with "Nubian mutes" (notes now amended).

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Yours sounded the funniest!

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Why "Assyrian mutes"? The statues look like this: www.flickr.com/photos/micsworld/8030416331/in/photostream/ www.flickr.com/photos/micsworld/8030420419/in/photostream/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Thank you!  The "princesses" (looks like an Egyptian to me) are either side of the main door, and the "slave-girls" are at the corners.  I thought they would be two sets of twins, but it looks as if each statue is different.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] 'Assyrian mutes' - At first I imagined that it might be the Freeman's journalist coming up with a learned-sounding phrase with an impending deadline. But it transpires that the Assyrian Empire,  by the 7th century BC, had expanded to included the Nile delta and the Nile to include Egypt and Nubia. Nevertheless it's difficult to see 'Nubian' and 'Assyrian'  as interchangeable terms.

As for 'mutes', I wondered if it was a synonym for 'statue', but the OED has nothing except 'mute as a statue'.

Having seen the close-ups, 'Nubian' seems a better fit than 'Assyrian'.
